title: 103_hr3843
content: The Act is titled the "Brownfield Cleanup and Redevelopment Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purpose section. The Congress finds that hundreds of obsolete industrial sites nationwide are polluted with environmental contamination, hindering their reuse and posing risks to nearby residents. The purpose of the Brownfield Cleanup and Redevelopment Act is to encourage cleanup and redevelopment of these sites. The Brownfield Cleanup and Redevelopment Act aims to encourage the cleanup and redevelopment of contaminated industrial sites, known as brownfields, as economically viable alternatives to undeveloped greenfield sites. SEC. 3. CERTIFICATION OF STATE VOLUNTARY CLEANUP PROGRAMS. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will establish certification criteria for State voluntary cleanup programs at eligible facilities within one year of the enactment of the Act. States meeting the criteria will be certified to conduct cleanup programs at eligible facilities instead of Federal programs. Biennial audits will be conducted to ensure State programs maintain certification. The Administrator will establish certification criteria for State voluntary cleanup programs at eligible facilities. Biennial audits will be conducted to ensure State programs maintain certification. If deficiencies are found, the State will be notified and given 6 months to resolve them before certification withdrawal. The program must only allow eligible facilities to participate and provide adequate opportunities. The program must provide public participation opportunities, technical assistance, oversight, and enforcement for voluntary cleanups at eligible facilities. The program must ensure that voluntary cleanups at eligible facilities comply with Federal and State laws, provide certification of completion from the State to the owner or purchaser, and exclude facilities eligible for abatement under another Act. Eligible facilities are those with environmental contamination that could hinder timely use or development, limited in scope, and easily evaluated. The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 identifies facilities subject to Federal enforcement actions, on the National Priorities List, or requiring permits under the Solid Waste Disposal Act. Facilities subject to closure notification, corrective action, or response assistance under various sections of the Solid Waste Disposal Act are identified as high priority for environmental enforcement actions. Facilities subject to closure notification, corrective action, or response assistance under the Solid Waste Disposal Act are high priority for environmental enforcement. No permits are required for cleanup under a certified state voluntary program.
